title-group.article-title: Alterations in nepetalactone metabolism during polyethylene glycol (PEG)- induced dehydration stress in two Nepeta species

Nepeta argolica Bory & Chaub. ssp. argolica

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Alterations in nepetalactone metabolism during polyethylene glycol (PEG)- induced dehydration stress in two
Nepeta species

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Neda Aničić, Dragana Matekalo, Marijana Skorić, Jasmina Nestorović Živković, Luka Petrović, Milan Dragićević, Slavica Dmitrović, Danijela Mišić ∗

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Department of Plant Physiology, Institute for Biological Research “Siniša Stanković”- National Institute of Republic of Serbia , University of Belgrade , Bulevar despota Stefana 142, 11060, Belgrade , Serbia

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Iridoid monoterpenoids Nepetalactone biosynthesis Transcription factors Dehydration stress
PEG
A B S T R A C T

A number of
Nepeta species
(fam. Lamiaceae ) are interesting medicinal crops for arid and semi-arid areas, due to their ability to maintain essential developmental and physiological processes and to rationalize their specialized metabolism under water deficit growth conditions. The present research is, to our knowledge, the first attempt to investigate the molecular background of the dehydration-induced changes in specialized metabolism of
Nepeta species
, which will help to understand relations between dehydration stress on one hand and biomass production and yield of nepetalactone (NL) on the other. During the 6 days exposure of
Nepeta rtanjensis Diklić & Milojević
and
Nepeta argolica Bory & Chaub. ssp. argolica
plants to PEG-induced dehydration stress under experimental in vitro conditions, decrease in transcript levels of the majority of 10 NL biosynthetic genes, and some of the 5 transcription factors (TFs) were recorded, simultaneously with the initial reduction in NL content. The two model species evidently employ similar strategies in response to severe dehydration stress; however
N. rtanjensis
is highlighted as the species more efficient in maintaining NL amounts in tissues. The results suggest trichome-specific and co-ordinately regulated NL biosynthesis at the level of gene expression, with trichome enriched MYC 2 and YABBY 5 TFs being the potential positive regulators. Manipulation of such TFs can be effective for engineering the NL biosynthetic pathway, and for the increased production of cis,trans -NL in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
and trans,cis -NL in
N. rtanjensis
.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
It has been proposed that NLs are derived throughout the general iridoid pathway, from geranyl pyrophosphate (GPP) produced by the MEP pathway, which arises in a reaction catalysed by geranyl pyrophosphate synthase (GPPS).
Nepeta species
share part of the monoterpene indole alkaloid (MIA) pathway with
Catharanthus roseus
up to 8-oxogeranial. The chain of reactions starts with geraniol synthase (GES) converting GPP to geraniol, which is then oxidized to 8-hydroxygeraniol in a reaction catalysed by geraniol 8-oxidase (G8 O ) (
). Subsequent oxidation of 8-hydroxygeraniol to yield dialdehyde 8-oxogeranial in
C. roseus
is catalysed by 8-hydroxygeraniol oxidoreductase (8-HGO) (
;
). The activity of 8-HGO has previously been confirmed for
Nepeta racemosa ( Hallahan et al., 1995 )
. The reaction that catalyses iridoid synthase ( IS ) was first described in
C. roseus
(Geu Flores et al., 2012). The two IS homologs from
N. mussinnii
and
N. cataria
have recently been functionally characterized (
). It has been shown that ISs of
Nepeta species
are responsible for the stereoselective 1,4- reduction of 8-oxogeranial (
,
;
). After forming the uncyclised and reactive enolate via ISmediated reduction, this intermediate is then cyclised to form nepetalactol by NAD-dependent nepetalactol-related short-chain-dehydrogenases/reductases (NEPSs) (
,
). Although an enzyme with NAD + oxidoreductase activity has been purified from
N. racemosa
leaves a long time ago (
), only recently three enzymes which control the formation of nepetalactol have been identified and functionally characterized from
N. mussinii ( Lichman et al., 2019a )
, NEPS1, NEPS2, and NEPS3. Apparently, NEPS1 is essential for the conversion of nepetalactol into NL.

The pools of bioactive compounds in
Nepeta species
are shaped by the external environmental factors. It has been reported that some
Nepeta species
modulate their essential oil content in response to drought and water stress (
;
;
). Some
Nepeta species
are considered attractive horticultural and medicinal crops in semi-arid areas, due to their adaptation to drought conditions and high production of essential oils. Many of them have previously been introduced into cultivation under extreme growth conditions, including
N. cataria
in Western Himalaya (
) and Burundi (
),
N. kotschyi
,
N. menthoides
,
N. crassifolia
, and
N. cataria ( Hadi et al., 2017 )
,
N. pogonosperma ( Ramezan and Abbaszadeh, 2016 )
and
Nepeta binaludensis ( Nadjafi et al., 2012 )
in Iran semi-arid and arid environmental conditions. Furthermore,
N. cataria ,
N. cataria var. citriodora
, and
N. grandiflora
are recognized as new medicinal crops suitable for cultivation in Egypt (
;
).

Two
Nepeta species
investigated within the present study,
Nepeta rtanjensis Diklić & Milojević
and
Nepeta argolica Bory & Chaub. ssp. argolica
(syn.
Nepeta sibthorpii Bentham
,
Nepeta argolica Bory & Chaub.
, according to Euro + Med PlantBase and The Plant List) are endemic plants of the Balkan Peninsula.
Nepeta argolica ssp. argolica
usually grows in dry stony places, rocky habitats, and scree of Greece (
), while
N. rtanjensis
inhabits calcareous stony grounds on the southern slopes of Mt Rtanj in SE Serbia (
). Although closely related, two model species display differential qualitative and quantitative content of NLs, with
N. rtanjensis
being a rich source of trans,cis -NL, and dehydronepetalactone (DNL), while in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
the major iridoid is cis,trans -NL (
). As water availability is the major challenge in natural habitats of the two species, it is essential to understand its effect on growth performance, overall physiology and water relations, leaf surface morphology, as well as on the NL metabolism. This is, to our knowledge, the first attempt to investigate the molecular background of the NL biosynthesis as influenced by dehydration stress, through evaluating the expression of metabolic pathway genes and regulatory genetic elements-transcription factors (TFs), in parallel with metabolic profiling.

sec.title: 2.1. Changes in physiological parameters as influenced by PEG
sec.p:
Turgor loss and fresh weight (FW) reduction were recorded in PEGtreated
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
shoots ( Fig. 1a–h, 1i, and 1k ), which have confirmed that plants are experiencing water stress. Reduced plant aerial biomass under PEG-induced stress ( Fig. 1i and k ) also indicated severely restricted
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
growth. The severity of stress conditions was validated through the analysis of the relative water content (RWC) in both non-treated and PEG-treated plants ( Fig. 1j and l ). The highest RWC values in
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants (an average of 65% and 72%, respectively) were recorded in non-treated plants and they were relatively stable throughout the experiment. Conversely, under water deficiency conditions, as expected, the RWC values of the PEG-treated plants were significantly declined, falling to their lowest values of 37% in
N. rtanjensis
and 35% in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
at 6DPT. Nonetheless, compared to the controls, the RWCs at all three experimental points (1DPT, 3DPT, and 6DPT) were significantly reduced, in both species. In PEG-treated
N. rtanjensis
plants RWC was lowered by 35%, while
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants experienced 45% reduction in RWC on average compared to non-treated plants. Regarding all the time points under the study, the water potential of −3 MPa in growing media could be considered as severe water stress for both analysed
Nepeta species.
However, the reduction of RWC was lower in
N. rtanjensis
than in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
, indicating that these two species respond differently to the same intensity of dehydration stress and that
N. rtanjensis
has developed a more efficient mechanism to cope with water deficiency.

sec.title: 2.2. Metabolic profile of nepetalactones as influenced by PEG
sec.p:
The identification of NL and DNL in samples was performed by exact mass search of their protonated pseudomolecular ions [M+ H ] + , MS 2 fragmentation patterns, by the comparison with pure compounds, as well as with the chromatographic and MS data available in the literature. UHPLC/MS 2 chromatogram of
N. rtanjensis
methanol extract revealed the presence of trans,cis -NL showing [M+ H ] + of m/z 167 at Rt = 6.97 min ( Fig. 2a ) and DNL with pseudomolecular ion [M+ H ] + of m/z 165 at Rt = 5.64 min ( Fig. 2b ). When
N. argolica ssp. argolica
methanol extract was analysed, cis,trans -NL showing [M+ H ] + of m/z 167 was identified as a peak eluting at Rt = 6.53 min ( Fig. 2f ), while DNL was recorded at Rt = 5.64 min (
Fig. 2g
). Characteristic SRM MS 2 fragments of NL and DNL in the positive ionization mode are presented within Fig. 2 . The identification of NL and DNL were additionally confirmed by DAD analysis. Absorption spectrum of NL isomers was characterized by the λ max at 230 nm , while DNL had a max absorption at λ max = 300 nm , which suggested the presence of a pyrone moiety in DNL (Ross, 1953), the conjugated lactone function with extended conjugation. Some previous studies revealed that nepetalactones in
Nepeta species
are usually present in the form of more than one isomer (reviewed in
), which is also suggested for
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica
. Taking into account that plants within the present study were grown under controlled in vitro conditions, which might significantly influence the specialized metabolism, it is not surprising that minor nepetalactones in these species were not recorded with the adopted analytical techniques.

A significant initial reduction of trans,cis -NL and DNL was observed in PEG-treated
N. rtanjensis
plants at 1DPT (~1.3 and ~1.4 fold, respectively) in comparison with the non-treated plants ( Fig. 2c and d ). This reduction was not statistically significant at 3DPT and 6DPT for trans,cis -NL and at 6DPT for DNL. In words of absolute content, trans,cis -NL slightly increases during the 6 days of PEG treatment, while DNL content decreases ( Fig. S1a and S1b ). The reduction in the content of cis,trans -NL (~2 fold) in PEG-treated
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants was significant at 1DPT, 3DPT and 6DPT when compared to non-treated plants ( Fig. 2h and i ). The amount of DNL was more influenced by PEG-treatment than was the amount of cis,trans -NL. The reduction in DNL content was significant at 1DPT and 3DPT, and was overcome at 6DPT, where no statistically significant differences between PEGtreated and non-treated plants were recorded ( Fig. 2i ). Following the initial stress response of plants to PEG treatment, which involves the reduction in cis,trans -NL and DNL content,
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants adapt to the stress conditions and compensate for the content of nepetalactones.

As previously speculated, the accumulation of NL, and therefore its amount in plant tissues, is controlled by the balance between the rate of formation and the rate of loss, the latter being a consequence of a direct release into the environment and/or conversion into its derivatives, such is DNL (
). As a means to evaluate the efficiency of NL catabolism and its conversion into DNL, we calculated the DNL/ trans,cis -NL or DNL/ cis,trans -NL ratio in
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
, respectively ( Fig. 2e and j ). The results point out that DNL/ cis,trans -NL ratio was significantly lower in PEG-treated
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants at 1DPT than in non-treated plants, presumably due to a very reduced DNL content. In
N. rtanjensis , DNL
/ trans,cis -NL ratio was relatively constant throughout the 6 days of PEG-treatment. We presumed that the rate of trans,cis -NL conversion into DNL was not influenced by PEG-treatment in
N. rtanjensis
plants, while in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
it was decreased.

According to the observations on various aromatic plants, water stress can decrease or enhance the level of essential oil content, depending on the species and magnitude of the stress conditions.
have shown that
N. racemosa
is a droughttolerant plant, which reaches the maximum capacity in essential oil production under moderate drought stress. Similarly,
N. pogonosperma
displayed the highest essential oil content in drought treated plants (
). Under osmotic stress conditions induced by PEG, the essential oil composition of
Mentha piperita
showed changes in the production of oxygenated monoterpenes, which included a decrease in menthone and an increase in menthofuran amount (
). Osmotic stress decreased pulegone levels and increased menthofuran levels in
M. piperita ( Charles et al., 1990 )
, suggesting that osmotic stress influences the oxidative and reductive transformations of pulegone (
).

sec.title: 2.3. The expression of nepetalactone biosynthetic genes during PEG-induced dehydration stress
sec.p:
Transcriptome analysis approach was applied for the identification of nepetalactone biosynthetic genes and related TFs, and their expression was further studied in parallel with the major nepetalactones content during the PEG-induced dehydration. Quantitative expression of
GPPS, GES, G8 O , 8HGO,
two
IS
candidates (
IS 1
and
IS 2
) was investigated in leaves of
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
at three different time points upon the start of PEG treatment (1DPT, 3DPT, and 6DPT). Moreover, the expression of four NEPS candidates ( NEPS1a, NEPS1b, NEPS2, and NEPS3 ) was analysed in
N. rtanjensis
and of two ( NEPS2 and NEPS3 ) in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
. Proposed biosynthetic pathway of nepetalactones in
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
and involved genes are presented in Fig. 3 .

It is well known that GPPS is a heteromeric enzyme structured of a non-catalytic small subunit (SSU) and a large subunit ( LSU ) (
). The SSU of GPPS complex is considered to remodel the LSU for the synthesis of C10-GPP, and is therefore responsible for controlling the production of volatile monoterpenes in mint (
). In our research, we selected to analyse the expression levels of a gene that corresponds to GPPS small subunit ( NrGPPS-SSU and NaGPPS-SSU ). In both
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
leaves the expression of GPPS-SSU was reduced throughout the experiment, and this reduction was statistically significant at 6DPT in
N. rtanjensis
, and at 1DPT in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
( Fig. 4a and b ).

The reaction catalysed by GES is considered a key gatekeeping step in iridoid biosynthesis, since this enzyme is responsible for diverting metabolic flux away from canonical monoterpenes by converting GPP to geraniol, which is further transformed into iridoids (
). Both
Nepeta species
showed a decreasing trend of the GES expression in response to PEG treatment. The expression of NrGES in leaves of
N. rtanjensis
was ~140-folds lower in PEG-treated plants compared to the respective non-treated plants at 6DPT ( Fig. 4a ), while in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
it dropped down by ~80-fold at 1DPT ( Fig. 4b ).

The relative expression values of
NrG8 O
in
N. rtanjensis
were not significantly changed in response to PEG-induced dehydration stress ( Fig. 4a ), while in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
NaG8 O
even shows an increase at 1DPT ( Fig. 4b ). Thus,
NrG8 O
and
NaG8 O
display different expression patterns in response to PEG-induced dehydration than all the other biosynthetic genes analysed here.
propose that G8 O is a gatekeeper between primary and secondary metabolism and therefore, a carbon flux controlling point of the iridoid pathway in
C. roseus
.
hypothesised that the opposite pattern of the
CrG8 O
expression in comparison with the other genes of secologanin pathway in
C. roseus
could indicate its role in the formation of other 10-hydroxygeranial derivatives that are unrelated to secologanin.

Expression patterns of 8HGO are similar to those of the other biosynthetic genes, showing significantly lower transcriptional levels in PEG-stressed plants already at 1DPT and steadily keeping them low throughout 6 days of the experiment ( Fig. 4a and b ). Treatment with PEG decreased the
N. rtanjensis Nr 8HGO
transcript levels down to ~4 fold ( Fig. 4a ) and
N. argolica ssp. argolica Na
8HGO transcript levels down to ~3 fold ( Fig. 4b ). The Nr8HGO found in transcriptomic database of
N. rtanjensis
is similar to Cr8HGOA in
C. roseus ( Miettinen et al., 2014 )
.

Lichman et al. (2019) have recently shown that NEPS enzymes of
N. mussinii
are cyclases, capable of accepting 8-oxocytronellyl enol/enolate, the product of IS , and cyclizing it to cis,trans - (NmNEPS1 and NmNEPS2) or cis,cis -nepetalactol (NmNEPS3). Oxidation of cis,trans - nepetalactol into cis,trans -NL and cis,cis -nepetalactol into cis,cis -NL goes via NmNEPS1. All functionally important residues of NmNEPS1 and NmNEPS3 were detected in NrNEPS1a and NrNEPS3 amino acid sequences, respectively. However, it was noticed that L156 and S198 of NmNEPS1 are substituted in NrNEPS1b with T157 and L198. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all NrNEPS candidates share a high level of amino acid identities with their
N. mussinii NEPS
homologs and with
M. piperita
(−)- trans -isopiperitenol dehydrogenase (ISPD) (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). Among analysed NEPS candidates, transcript levels of NrNEPS1a and NrNEPS2 were the most abundant in
N. rtanjensis leaves
( Fig. S1e ), and we presumed that they are somehow responsible for the formation of trans,cis -NL. The transcripts of NaNEPS1a and NaNEPS1b were not recorded in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
, species rich in cis,trans -NL, while NaNEPS2 showed the highest levels of expression in this species in comparison with the other NEPSs ( Fig. S1f ). The candidates of NEPS genes were searched in available
N. rtanjensis
transcriptome, and the same set of qPCR primers were used for the expression analysis of NrNEPS s, as well as for NaNEPS s. Although the two species are closely related, those primers might fail to amplify the corresponding NaNEPS1 sequences from
N. argolica ssp. argolica
. In
N. rtanjensis
the expressions of NrNEPS1a , NrNEPS1b , and NrNEPS3 exhibited significant decreases in PEG-treated plants at 1DPT, 3DPT, and 6DPT ( Fig. 4a ). Although NrNEPS2 expression was reduced in response to PEG treatment, this reduction was significant only at 6DPT. Decreased expression of NaNEPS2 was observed in PEG-treated
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants, while NaNEPS3 transcription levels were significantly increased in PEG-dehydrated plants ( Fig. 4b ). Our results indicate that all the analysed NEPS candidates, with the exception of NaNEPS3 , were involved in the modulation of nepetalactone biosynthesis in response to dehydration stress.

It has been previously reported for many species that biosynthesis of specialized metabolites is modulated in response to water deficit conditions, by alterations at the gene expression level. Thus,
have shown that the expressions of structural genes involved in artemisin biosynthesis decrease concomitant to the artemisin content in
Artemisia annua
essential oil under prolonged water deficit stress. In
Salvia dolomitica
both moderate and severe drought stress conditions led to the modulation of the expression of some genes involved in sesquiterpene production, and to the increase of their content (
). The lower expression of NL biosynthetic genes under PEGinduced dehydration stress conditions implies a decrease in the metabolite flux through the NL biosynthetic pathway. This was partially supported by the metabolomics data, which revealed the decrease in cis,trans -NL and DNL content in leaves of
N. argolica ssp. argolica
( Fig. 2h, i ). In
N. rtanjensis
, this decrease was less pronounced and it was significant only at 1DPT for trans,cis -NL and at 1DPT and 3DPT for DNL ( Fig. 2c, d ). Interestingly, at 6DPT the content of DNL in PEG-dehydrated
N. argolica ssp. argolica
and
N. rtanjensis
plants was at the level of non-treated plants, which indicated that they probably adapted to the new stress conditions by enabling more intense conversion of NL to less volatile DNL.
2.4. Transcriptional regulation of nepetalactone metabolism in N. rtanjensis and N. argolica ssp. argolica leaves

We have presumed that NL biosynthesis is coordinated by jasmonate (JA)-signalling pathway, based on the well-established regulatory circuit of iridoid biosynthesis in
C. roseus
(
;
). With the aim to discover sequences similar to TFs that are specifically controlling monoterpene biosynthesis in glandular trichomes of the related Lamiaceae species BLAST search was performed. Sequences of three genes homologous to TFs putatively involved in JA-signaling ( COI1, JAZ3 and MYC2 ) were identified in
N. rtanjensis
transcriptome, whereas no hits of sequences similar to ORCA and BIS group of TFs were found. Additionally, sequences highly similar to the ones encoding the regulators of monoterpene biosynthesis in spearmint – MsMYB and MsYABBY5 (
,
) have also been identified in the transcriptome of
N. rtanjensis
. The expression levels of 5 candidate TFs ( COI1 , JAZ3 , MYC2 , MYB, and YABBY5 ) were analysed in leaves of
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
under PEG-induced dehydration conditions and further correlated with the expressions of NL biosynthetic pathway genes. Phylogenetic analysis of amino acid sequences of these TFs was constructed to assign each of them to the correct clade and to show the evolutionary relationship with TFs from different species ( Fig. S3 ). In addition, the specific domains of each of the analysed
N. rtanjensis
candidate proteins were identified in the alignments with sequences of different species and their subclading with the sequences from species of Lamiaceae could further support their identities ( Fig. S3 ). The domains included F-box and Leu-rich repeats for NrCOI1, TIFY and Jas for NrJAZ3, JID and bHLH for NrMYC2, R2 and R3 repeats and bHLH motifs for NrMYB as well as Zinc finger and HMG-like YABBY domain for NrYABBY5.

The gene for the first enzyme of JA-signalling cascade — COI1 exhibited stable expression in
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
in the dehydration stress conditions ( Fig. 5a and b ). Concurrently, JAZ3 expression remained unchanged throughout the experiment in both non-treated and PEG-treated plants of both species ( Fig. 5a and b ). The unchanged expressions of COI1 and
JAZ 3
in response to water scarcity could indicate that JA is either not a dominant part of the regulating network of nepetalactones biosynthesis during severe dehydration stress, or that JA-signalling cascade onsets in the early stages of the drought stress response, that were not analysed within this experiment. In confirmation of the latter hypothesis, a study by
pointed out that the JA concentrations are fluctuating and seem to accumulate during the early stages of water stress.
have shown that drought as a stress signal favours accumulation of ABA and JA precursor 12-OPDA, by uncoupling its further conversion to JA and blocking the JA-signalling. Although the expression of COI1 and JAZ3 was stable within the present study, the expression level of MYC2 , which is known to be repressed by the JAZ proteins in the absence of JAs and the central TF of JA-signalling pathway, was changed during the dehydration stress. In both
Nepeta species
, MYC2 was significantly down-regulated under PEG-treatment throughout the whole experiment ( Fig. 5a and b ), which followed the patterns of changes in the expression of the majority of biosynthesis genes. Since MYC2 is known to be a signalling hub, where phytohormonal signals overlap, its expression levels could be controlled by ABA in
Nepeta
leaves during dehydration stress conditions. Unlike JAs, concentrations of abscisic acid (ABA), the major hormone controlling plant water loss, usually increases as tissue water status drops (
).

The expression of MYB was significantly up-regulated in
N. rtanjensis
at 6DPT and is down-regulated in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
at 1DPT ( Fig. 5a and b ). Previous results suggest that spearmint MsMYB is a negative regulator of monoterpene biosynthesis, which binds to cis - elements of MsGPPS.LSU and suppresses its expression (
). Phylogenetic analysis of
N. rtanjensis NrMYB
revealed high levels of homology with MsMYB ( Fig. S3 ), suggesting its role as a negative regulator of NL biosynthesis.
reported that MsYABBY5 is preferentially expressed in peltate glandular trichomes of
Mentha spicata
leaves and that the encoded TF is probably a repressor of specialized metabolism. Other studies have revealed that YABBYs act either as repressors or activators, and are therefore bi-functional (
;
). Within the present study, PEG-induced water deficiency triggered down-regulation of YABBY TFs in both
Nepeta species
in all analysed time points and their expression values were positively correlated with those of NL-biosynthesis genes. This led us to presume that NrYABBY5 and NaYABBY5 are positive regulators of nepetalactone metabolism. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that
N. rtanjensis YABBY
candidate ( NrYABBY5 ) shares a high level of homology with
Mentha spicata MsYABBY
5 ( Fig. S3 ).

Hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) was conducted in order to obtain a better insight regarding the associations among NL biosynthetic genes and TFs involved in the regulation of NL metabolism during PEGinduced dehydration stress in two analysed
Nepeta species.
Based on the presented tree ( Fig. 5c ), two separated clusters are noticeable for
N. rtanjensis
. Cluster A contains NrCOI1 , NrJAZ3 , and NrMYB TFs, which are grouped with NrIS1 and NrG8O . The rest of the biosynthetic genes cluster together with NrMYC2 and NrYABBY5 TFs within the cluster B. Two clusters are also visible in the HCA dendrogram of
N. argolica ssp. argolica
; cluster A containing NaJAZ3 and NaCOI1 TFs, NaG8O and NaNEPS3 , and cluster B was comprising NaMYB, NaMYC2 and NaYABBY5 TFs and the majority of NL biosynthetic genes. Correlation analysis of NL biosynthetic genes and TFs expression patterns was carried out to further confirm the associations between and among NL biosynthetic genes and TFs ( Fig. 5c and d ). Generally, positive correlations have been observed between the analysed biosynthetic genes, suggesting their co-ordinated regulation. Significant positive correlations between NL biosynthetic genes on the one hand, and YABBY5 and MYC2 TFs on the other, suggested their role as positive regulators of NL biosynthesis in leaves of both
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
. Negative correlations between MYB TF and the majority of biosynthetic genes were recorded in
N. rtanjensis
, while NaMYB exhibited no significant correlations with the other analysed genes in
N. argolica ssp. argolica
. The expression of NrG8O and NrIS1 was not significantly correlated with the expression of other biosynthetic genes in
N. rtanjensis
but was significantly positively correlated with NrCOI1 . In the case of
N. argolica ssp. argolica
, NaG8O showed no positive correlations with the rest of the biosynthetic genes but displayed significant positive correlations with NaCOI1 .
2.5. Trichome-specific nepetalactone biosynthesis in N. rtanjensis leaves

We were further interested in analysing whether all the NL biosynthesis-related genes and selected TFs are expressed together in the same tissue-trichomes of
N. rtanjensis
. The expression of 10 structural genes putatively involved in NL biosynthesis was analysed ( NrGPPS, NrGES, NrG8O, Nr8HGO, NrIS1, NrIS2 NrNEPS1.1, NrNEPS1.2, NrNEPS2 and NrNEPS3 ) by comparing their transcript levels in detached trichomes and abraded leaves of
N. rtanjensis
. The results revealed the significantly higher expression of all the analysed genes in detached trichomes in comparison with the abraded leaves ( Fig. 6a ), which indicated the trichome localization of the nepetalactone biosynthetic pathway from geraniol to NL. In our previous study, we have shown that the two IS candidates ( NrIS1 and NrIS2 ) were differentially expressed in
N. rtanjensis
trichomes and abraded leaves, and that the spatial patterning of NrIS1 and NrIS2 expression is in correlation with the content of nepetalactones (
). Comparative proteome analysis of trichomes, trichome-depleted leaves and leaves of
N. mussinii
, showed that all analysed proteins, including NmGPPS-SSU, NmGES, NmG8H, NmHGOA, NmHGOB, and NmISY2, were significantly trichome enriched (
).

Similarly to the structural genes, the majority of TF genes exhibited significantly higher expression levels in detached trichomes of
N. rtanjensis
( Fig. 6b ). Namely, NrCOI1, NrJAZ3, NrMYC2 and NrYABBY5 are predominantly expressed in leaf trichomes, which further supports the hypothesis about their involvement in trichome-specific metabolic processes. The trichome-localized expression and positive correlations between expression patterns of YABBY5 and MYC2 TFs and the majority of NL pathway structural genes during dehydration stress further implicates the relevance of these TFs to NL biosynthesis.

sec.title: 3. Concluding remarks
sec.p:
As revealed by the presented results, the expression of NL-related biosynthetic genes and TFs is co-ordinately down-regulated in response to PEG-induced dehydration stress and was well correlated with metabolite pools, which suggests that NL biosynthesis is controlled at the gene expression level. This was less visible in the case of
N. rtanjensis ,
where NL pools remained relatively stable throughout the dehydration experiment despite the decreased metabolic flux through the iridoid pathway. Taking into account that plants within the present study experienced severe stress, it would be interesting to see the changes during moderate and prolonged dehydration stress. Providing those data would be useful to improve the cultivation management and increase the productivity of
Nepeta
crops in arid and semi-arid areas. Being the potential positive regulators of NL biosynthesis, trichome enriched NrMYC2 and NrYABBY5 TFs are highlighted as good candidates for metabolic engineering, and therefore their isolation and functional characterization are the course of our further work. Manipulation of such TFs can be more effective for engineering NL biosynthetic pathway rather than changing the expression of genes for individual enzymes involved. A challenge for future studies will also be to identify other molecular players involved in the regulation of nepetalactone metabolism, which might act in a network with NrMYC2 and NrYABBY5 TFs, as well as to find their connections with phytohormones (e.g., JA , ABA ) signalling networks. Growing knowledge on the NL metabolism regulation will aid in the development of new production techniques for increased yield of cis,trans -NL in
N. argolica
ssp. argolica
and trans,cis -NL in
N. rtanjensis
, and/or in adequate heterologous systems.

sec.title: 4.1. Plant material and PEG experiment setup
sec.p:
Four weeks old, rooted shoots of a uniform developmental stage were used in PEG experiment. The plants were transferred to sucrose-free liquid ½ MS culture medium supplemented with PEG 8000, which provided a final osmotic pressure of −3 MPa, while non-treated plants were grown in sucrose-free liquid medium containing only ½ MS salts. The addition of PEG 8000 ( 530.3 g l −1 ) to the culture medium was performed after the sterilization of medium by autoclaving at 114 °C for 25 min, and subsequent cooling to room temperature. To calculate the final water potential of the culture media with the addition of PEG, we utilized the
equation: Ψ = 1.29 [PEG] 2 T–140 [PEG] 2 –4.0 [PEG], [PEG] = g PEG/g H 2 O ; T = +25 °C. Both non-treated and PEG-treated plants were grown in 6.5 × 6.5 × 10 cm Magenta vessels (SigmaAldrich, Germany ) containing 30 ml of the respective medium. Leaves of the non-treated and treated plants were collected after 1, 3, and 6 days of PEG treatment (DPT), ground in liquid N 2 and immediately stored at −80 °C until further use. Samples were harvested in three parallel experiments, which represented three biological replicates.

The trichome isolation was performed as previously described in
.

sec.title: 4.2. Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was applied on the leaves of non-treated and PEG-treated
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
plants at 1, 3 and 6 DPT. Samples were coated with a thin layer of gold and palladium in a BAL-TEC SCD 005 sputter coater (BAL-TEC, Germany ). Both adaxial and abaxial surfaces were examined with a JEOL JSM-6390 LV (JEOL, Tokyo , Japan ) scanning electron microscope operated at 15 KV.

sec.title: 4.3. Determination of the relative water content (RWC)
sec.p: The relative water content (RWC) of plants was calculated according to the following formula (Slayter, 1967): RWC (%) = [(FW-DW)/(TW-DW)] × 100. Fresh weight (FW) of both non-treated and PEG-treated plants was measured on the day of sampling. Next, all plants were immersed in distilled water for 24 h at room temperature and subsequently weighted (turgid weight− TW). After drying for 72 h at 70 °C, when the samples reached the constant weight, they were measured for their dry weight (DW). All experimental points and their respective controls were measured in biological triplicates.

sec.title: 4.4. Preparation of methanol extracts
sec.p: Samples powdered in LN were lyophilized for 24 h. Subsequently, 5 mg (DW) of each sample was extracted with 500 μl 99.8% methanol (AppliChem GmbH, Germany ) by vortexing for 20 s. Samples were subsequently extracted overnight in a fridge (4 °C) and next day sonicated in an ultrasonic bath (RK100, Bandelin, Berlin , Germany ) for 10 min. Following centrifugation for 10 min at 8000 g , supernatants were filtered through 0.2 μm syringe filters (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA ), and stored at 4 °C until use.

sec.title: 4.5. UHPLC/(+)HESI-MS/MS quantification of targeted nepetalactones
sec.p:
Dionex Ultimate 3000 UHPLC system (ThermoFisher Scientific, Germany ) connected to TSQ Quantum Access Max triple-quadrupole mass spectrometer (ThermoFisher Scientific, Switzerland ) was used for determination and quantification of NL and DNL in methanol extracts of
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
leaves. Elution was performed at 40 °C on Hypersil gold C18 column (50 × 2.1 mm ) with 1.9 μm particle size (ThermoFisher Scientific, USA ). The mobile phase, gradient elution, and the flow rate were set according to
, and the injection volume was 10 μl. Vaporizer temperature of mass spectrometer equipped with heated electrospray ionization (HESI) source was kept at 300 °C, and ion source settings were as follows: spray voltage 4000 V, sheath gas (N 2 ) pressure 28 AU, ion sweep gas pressure 1.0 AU, auxiliary gas (N 2 ) pressure 10 AU, capillary temperature 275 °C, and skimmer offset 0 V. Mass spectrometry data were acquired in a positive mode, and collision-induced fragmentations were performed using argon, with collision energy (cE) set to 30 eV. Selected reaction monitoring (SRM) experiments for quantitative analysis were performed using two characteristic MS 2 fragments for each compound. Both DNL and NL were identified by direct comparison either with
N. rtanjensis
essential oil (EO) containing 72% of trans,cis -NL and 16% of cis,trans -NL, as previously described in
, and with the literature data. Authenticity of cis,trans -NL, trans,cis -NL and DNL in samples was additionally confirmed by comparing the DAD, MS and MS 2 spectra with the pure compounds isolated from
N. rtanjensis
and
N. cataria
. The amounts of trans,cis -NL, cis,trans -NL, and DNL were evaluated by calculating the peak areas, based on the calibration curve of 8- oxogeranial (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, USA ). The stock standard solution was prepared by dissolving 1 mg of 8-oxogeranial in 1 ml methanol, and was further diluted with methanol down to 1 ng ml −1 , to obtain calibration levels within the range from 20 μg ml −1 to 1 ng ml −1 . Regression was calculated for the calibration curve, which showed good linearity (r = 0.999, p <0.001). Amounts were calculated as ng of 8-oxogeranial equivalents per mg of dry weight (ng mg −1 DW), and results for PEG-treated plants are presented relatively, in respect to the corresponding control (non-treated plants). All the analyses were performed in triplicates.

sec.title: 4.6. Selection of candidate genes and qPCR analysis
sec.p:
For elucidating the biosynthetic pathway of nepetalactone we have used the transcriptome database of
N. rtanjensis leaves
available in our laboratory (data not published). The RNA-seq data were generated by Illumina platform HiSeq 2500. By performing a BLAST search with already characterized genes from
C. roseus
and
Mentha spicata
, the candidates for all genes potentially involved in NL biosynthesis and regulation have been identified. These included 10 candidate structural genes involved in nepetalactone biosynthesis ( GPPS , GES , G80 , 8HGO ,
IS 1
,
IS 2
, NEPS1a , NEPS1b , NEPS2 , and NEPS3 ) and 5 transcription factors (
COI 1
, JAZ3 ,
MYC 2
,
MYB
, and
YABBY 5
). All of the candidates have shown high similarity to the corresponding genes present in the NCBI database. As the endogenous control for qPCR analysis in PEGexperiment, we used glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) gene, which was also retrieved from the RNA-seq of
N. rtanjensis leaves
. For the NCBI accession numbers of the candidate genes, please refer to Table S2. Based on these sequences, highly specific primer pairs were designed using Primer3Plus software (http:// www.bioinformatics.nl/cgi-bin/primer3plus/primer3plus.cgi) (Table S1). Finally, 18S rRNA was used as the housekeeping gene for qPCR analysis (
) in experiment with trichomes and abraded leaves, as previously reported by
. Since the transcriptome database of
N. argolica ssp. argolica
was unavailable and this species is closely related to
N. rtanjensis
, we have used the same set of primers in the gene expression analysis of these two species, and sequenced the qPCR products to confirm their composition.

The RNA extraction from leaf samples of
N. rtanjensis
and
N. argolica ssp. argolica
from the PEG-experiment was performed applying a modified CTAB method (
). RNA was quantified with N60 Nano-Photometer ® (Implen GmbH, Munich, Germany ) and fluorometrically (Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer, ThermoFisher Scientific, USA ), and its integrity was confirmed with gel electrophoresis. Obtained total RNA was treated with DNase I (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA ) for 30 min at 37 °C. From 1 μg of total RΝΑ cDNA was constructed using the Revert Aid First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (ThermoFisher Scientific, USA ) following manufacturers' specifications, with oligo-(dT) primers (Life Technologies, USA ). The PCR mixture comprised of cDNA corresponding to 50 ng of total RNA, 1 μM primers, 1U of Phusion Hot Start II High-Fidelity polymerase (Thermo Scientific, USA ) in a volume of 50 μl. The amplification was carried out in an Eppendorf Mastercycler Nexus (Eppendorf, Germany ) thermal cycler with the following amplification profile: initial denaturation (30 s at 98 °C), followed by 40 cycles of denaturation (10 s at 98 °C), annealing (30 s at 60 °C), and extension (45 s at 72 °C) with final extension (7 min at 72 °C). The obtained amplicons were purified electrophoretically, extracted from the gel using GeneJET Gel extraction kit (Thermo Scientific, USA ), quantified and serially diluted in a 10 9 -10 2 copies/μl range to be used as standards for the absolute qPCR quantification. Total RNA from
N. rtanjensis
trichomes and abraded leaves, sampled using dry ice leaf abrasion protocol previously described in
, was isolated with the commercial Spectrum Plant Total RNA Kit (Sigma, USA ), according to the manufacturers’ specifications.

sec.title: 4.7. Statistical analysis
4.8. Phylogenetic analysis
sec.p:
Protein sequences of known short-chain dehydrogenases and putative
N. rtanjensis
NrNEPSs were aligned using Muscle software within the MEGA 6.0 software package. The default parameters of Gblocks v0.91b were utilized to trim divergent regions of the alignments and select blocks of alignment positions that are highly conserved. The phylogenetic analyses of the conserved blocks of the alignments were conducted by the maximum likelihood method using MEGA version 6.0 with the default settings (NNI heuristic method, BioNJ initial tree, JTT model and 1000 bootstrap replicates). For phylogenetic analysis of transcription factors, the evolutionary history was inferred using the Neighbor-Joining method. The percentages of replicate trees in which the associated taxa clustered together in the bootstrap test (1000 replicates) are shown next to the branches. The tree is drawn to scale, with branch lengths in the same units as those of the evolutionary distances used to infer the phylogenetic tree. The evolutionary distances were computed using the Poisson correction method and are in the units of the number of amino acid substitutions per site. All ambiguous positions were removed for each sequence pair (pairwise deletion option). Evolutionary analyses were conducted in MEGA X. Multiple sequence alignments were generated using the ClustalW program. For a list of plant protein sequences used for phylogenetic analysis and their corresponding accession numbers refer to Table S2.
